content: We make scatterplots to see relationships between variables. Scatterplots are really good for helping us see if two variables have positive or negative correlation (or no correlation at all).

##Problem 1: Flower height and petal length

Sean measured the height and petal length (in centimeters) of all the flowers in his garden.  

|||||||
:-- | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: | --: 
**Height $(\text{cm})$** | $30$ | $20$ | $15$ | $35$ | $10$ | $40$ 
**Petal length $(\text{cm})$**| $6$ | $4$ | $2$ | $8$ | $1.5$ | $8.5$

[[☃ graded-group 1]]  

[[☃ graded-group 2]]  

[[☃ graded-group 3]]

options.content:
**Plot the data in a scatterplot.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
Let's plot each point, with its $x$-coordinate coming from the *height* and the $y$-coordinate coming from the corresponding *petal length*.

**The final graph looks like this:**  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/333b06f6d658c349663413f67435ea2d2bb5895a)

options.title: question a

options.content:
**What is the best description of the relationship between height and petal length for Sam's flowers?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
An example of each type of correlation is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

**The answer for Sam's flowers:**

**Positive correlation**

options.title: question b

options.content:
**Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the correlation?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
We can look at it this way:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/016eb38387c9d8aca24ccfbb6462446da7b00352)

**तो हमारा उत्तर है:**

**Taller flowers tended to have longer petals.**

options.title: question c

choices.content: Taller flowers tended to have shorter petals.
Taller flowers tended to have longer petals.
There was no clear relationship between flower height and petal length.

content:
##Problem 2: Car driver age

Data was recorded on the age of drivers and the number of car accidents per $100$ drivers in the year $2009$. The data is shown in the scatter plot below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ffa167e6740a1093649c055b2edff49e66268c7d)

[[☃ graded-group 4]]  

[[☃ graded-group 5]]

options.content:
**What is the best description of the relationship between age and the number of car accidents?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
An example of each type of correlation is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

**तो हमारा उत्तर है:**

**Negative correlation**

options.title: question A

options.content:
**Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the correlation?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
We can look at it this way:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4dca991398791176acef23ae38c7c644fd139db0)

**तो हमारा उत्तर है:**

**Older drivers tended to have fewer accidents.**

options.title: question b

choices.content: The older drivers tended to have fewer accidents.
The older drivers tended to have more accidents.
There was no clear relationship between age and the number of accidents.

content:
##Problem 3: Shoe sizes and test scores

Dexter's class recorded data on the test grades and shoe sizes of students in the class. The data is shown in the scatter plot below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f6796dc096fa83db33f8cda991c286a591801f17)

[[☃ graded-group 6]]  

[[☃ graded-group 7]]

options.content:
**What is the best description of the relationship between shoe size and test scores?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
An example of each type of correlation is shown below. 

$\greenD{\text{Positive correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2fa017d9cd398ffcc94396fb5300fb01415eb70c)

$\maroonD{\text{Negative correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7369fbf2eb900d2a7b7ec4f8502859ac5ef88e80)

$\goldD{\text{No correlation}}$  
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/546edc63617e4a9980f6874288f4a6c949f22a9a)

**तो हमारा उत्तर है:**

**No correlation**

options.title: question a

options.content:
**Which statement is the most accurate interpretation of the correlation?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
There doesn't seem to be any correlation between shoe size and test scores; the scores are about as high for students with big feet as for students with small feet.

**तो हमारा उत्तर है:**

**There was no clear relationship between shoe size and test scores.**

options.title: question b

choices.content: Students with bigger shoe sizes tended to score higher on the test.
Students with bigger shoe sizes tended to score lower on the test.
There was no clear relationship between shoe size and test scores.
